instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DOES NOT GO OFF WITH THE  POWER BUTTON
threads.message: Hello guys , have got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that the left fan runs really high ,and does not respond when I press and hold the power button to switch the machine off ( PLEASE NOTE THAT THE MACHINE POWERS UP AND BOOTS OKAY )  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> remains high at 3.3V when I press the power Botton , even when I short the SW5200 on board, the signal does not go low. I. have replaced the SMC but still no changes , by the way <SIGNAL>SMC_ON</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>OFF_L</SIGNAL> signal is present at 3.3V .. please where do I go from here ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DOES NOT GO OFF WITH THE  POWER BUTTON
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMC_ON</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>OFF_L</SIGNAL> signal is present at 3.3V"
Does it drop when pressing power button?

Start in diagnostic mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DOES NOT GO OFF WITH THE  POWER BUTTON
threads.message: yes ,<SIGNAL>SMC_ON</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>OFF_L</SIGNAL> signal drops upon pressing the power button
